fields.label_text:
This collection of silver slices, all commissioned over a period of twenty years by Professor Benton Seymour Rabinovitch FRS, is proof of the skill and diversity of contemporary silversmiths.  Each artist craftsman has responded to the familiar functional form of the slice in an individual way, producing an astonishingly diverse range of interpretations.  Each piece becomes an enchanting, decorative work of art. Professor Rabinovitch established a close rapport with each artist, always encouraging a freedom of creative expression.  The response of these silversmiths has been not only to be strikingly imaginative but also to honour him by giving him their best work.

This collection is testimony to the significant contribution that one individual can make to supporting the craft of silversmithing.  After commissioning work from some of the most illustrious names in British and North American silversmithing, Professor Rabinovitch has very generously donated his entire collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, through the American Friends of the V&A.

fields.descriptive_line: Silver, London hallmarks for 2002, mark of Michael Rowe

fields.name: The Rabinovitch Collection
fields.venue: Victoria and Albert Museum, The Whiteley Silver Galleries

fields.name: The Rabinovitch Collection of Fish and Cake Servers

fields.physical_description: The bold concept of this piece demands the viewer's attention and invites individual interpretation of its abstract style. The curvilinear form of the piece is suggestive of water. The flat blade and part of the handle are polished to a high shine, offsetting the unpolished handle. The handle itself rises effortlessly to form a powerful "post"; this change in gradient is strikingly delineated by a sharp change in surface finish. This piece captures a sense of power in its bold and assertive design.

After commissioning work from some of the most illustrious names in British and North American silversmithing, Professor Rabinovitch has very generously donated his entire collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, through the American Friends of the V&A. [2005]
fields.marks:
London hallmarks for 2002
 Mark of Michael Rowe
fields.public_access_description: This bold abstract design uses geometrical principles to construct a piece that is strikingly original yet has a timeless balance and sense of proportion.
fields.exhibition_history:
The Rabinovitch Collection (Victoria and Albert Museum 19/05/2005-25/01/2007)
The Rabinovitch Collection of Fish and Cake Servers (Fairfax House, York 26/09/2009-31/12/2009)
fields.bibliography: Benton Seymour Rabinovitch, <u>Contemporary Silver, Part II: Recent Commissions</u>, Seattle, 2005, pp. 36-37. ill.
fields.credit: Given by the American Friends of the V&A through the generosity of Professor B. Seymour Rabinovitch
fields.history_note:
Fairfax House Fish & Cake Slice exhibition RF.2004/419

Historical significance: Rowe's abstract style delights in contradiction. He searches to combine "ambiguity with insight, surprise with familiarity, coherence with risk". The simplicity of his designs illustrate the "distilled economy" of  form that he employs to enhance their dramatic impact. The geometrical principles that govern all forms are strongly in evidence in his designs.
fields.historical_context_note: Part of a collection of fish slices commissioned by Professor Rabinovitch from contemporary North American and British makers.
